perfect opportunity to introduce to you our next project this bad ass ship this
project is a project that will wow your players it can be a little bit
intimidating but the hardest part about building something like this is laying
it all out and I'm a real swell guy so I did that for you this is another
template build so if you go over to drive through RPG the full length link
is in the description below you can download and print out the template for
this boat that you can use to cut out all your pieces and all the guesswork is
done for you and you need to put it together and paint it customize it as
I'm going to mention in the tutorial there's two sails you can print out one
has a pattern on it like a sail texture that looks a little bit more realistic
and one that's just blank in case you don't have a color printer or you want
to do your own thing with on white paper with washes the way this thing is built
the mast comes off and the sail is actually removable so you can make a
whole bunch of different ones and keep your using this project add logos to
your sails depending on plans or whoever owns the boat this is a cool project so
let's go over and make a ship alright once you've downloaded the template from
drive-thru RPG you can carefully cut out all of the pieces
you're going to want to join the front and back parts of the ship base as well
as the front and back of the ship sides and just a quick check to make sure
everything lines up and grab yourself some half-inch
extruded polystyrene take glue stick just go around the edge of your piece
and glue it on top you can use this as a guide to cut out the shape do this
slowly take a few passes to make sure you get a nice square clean cut then you
can peel off the template and put it aside to reuse it in the future if you'd
like you're going to repeat the same process with the side pieces except here
you're going to use the dollar store foam core with both pieces of paper
ripped off once you have this cut out you can peel off the paper stick it to
another piece and do it again you need two sides now we're going to start
putting some wood planking on the ship base here I just gridded out half inch
spaces and drew some continuous lines I go through with a x-acto knife and score
in maybe about an eighth of an inch deep channel and then I take a ballpoint pen
and run it through a few times to create a indent
then go through and draw in some cross lines to show where the planks begin and
end and if you'd like you can poke in some dots to show nail holes now I'm
drawing the planks on the side panel here I'm not marking anything out
because they're curved lines I'm just using a technique called finger gauging
where basically you take your finger and write it along the edge of your piece to
get a fairly smooth line but you can just freehand this then obviously repeat
the same pattern on your other side panel now on the inside of these panels
I decided to do vertical planks just to give it a bit different of a look from
the outside now for the figurehead I chose the wolf but there's also a dragon
head included in the template here I've just glued the pattern onto the
dollar-store foam core and I'm cutting it out with a hot wire scroll table you
could do this with an exacto knife if you're very careful but I do have the
scroll table and it makes this cut a lot easier now for some added effect I'm
just going through and tracing in some design this is really just free handed
so you can do kind of whatever you'd like a keen eye will notice that this is
modeled heavily off the Game of Thrones House Stark 1 so you can take a look at
that sigil for reference I also decided to add some runes to the to the shaft
here just to kind of dress it up and here I have all my pieces cut out
you can see I also did the two triangular pieces for the front and the
back which again has the drawn-out wood planks now to give this some really
realistic wood texture you want to get a stiff wire brush you can buy these at
the hardware store I got a three pack of these from Home Depot for like four
dollars just take this and run it along the length of the planks not pressing
too hard and trust me it gives it a very very nice wood grain look to it and make
sure you get all the edges including the tops I also broke the corners with an
emery board alright once you have all your parts ready it's time to assemble
and we're going to do this using white glue and pins you can see here I forgot
to draw in the planking on these pieces on the edge so I'm doing it now so you
want to use full strength PVA glue brush it on the entire surface and then place
your piece and start pinning it together the nice thing about this project is
that it has all those little nail holes in the board's so if you'd like rather
than temporarily pinning you can do what I'm doing here and actually put the pins
in all the way and leave them in there permanently this will give the whole
thing a lot of extra strength and honestly add quite a bit to the finished
look this part is a little tedious but take
your time with it make sure everything lines up nicely and this is the really
great thing about working from a template when you join these pieces up
this should all be the right length and once you're happy with your sides you
can glue in the figure head use lots of glue and take your time making sure it's
sitting nicely I used three pins that I carefully
pierced all the way through and these ones are going to stay in there
permanently I then brushed in a little bit of extra glue on over top afterwards
then you just repeat the same process with the back piece now take some glue
and run it along all the seams try to fill them in and give everything a lot
more strength don't be shy here coat it up in glue
then once that's dry I coated the whole thing in a watered-down PVA glue this
will make the whole thing a lot more stiff and it also protects a styrofoam
if you decide to spray-paint I personally didn't spray paint this black
because I didn't want to take the risk of anything melting after this much work
was put into it and hand brushing it didn't seem like too big of a deal now
we're going to put a coat of dark brown on any kind you have on hand will do
cover the whole thing fairly watered down let it get into all the crevices
there it's starting to look pretty good then here I have kind of tan brown that
will be my final highlight but first I took it and mixed it with the brown to
do a kind of medium in between to do my first dry brushing I covered the entire
surface then once that's done I did my final dry brushing with the tan unmixed
last I took a very very watery black wash and tested it out on a few spots
made sure I liked it and then went ahead and covered the whole thing in this wash
this gave everything a nice aged look but more importantly it really brought
out all those really fine woodgrain textures from the wire brush and for the
mast I took a large dowel at 9 inches long in a small dowel at 5 inches long I
cut a small groove and the large one that the small one could fit into I
wanted to the ends to have a kind of human look so I sanded them all down
then to make these look more like hand chiseled logs
I took my knife and just started carving them up this really helps to make them
not look just like store-bought craft sticks then I just glue the two pieces
together and for the base I found this plastic piece that I had lying around I
don't know what it's from but you can use a lid or a washer this one just
happened to fit the dowel nicely and I used some goop to attach it I decided
that I wanted to use some toothpicks as some side supports so I drilled in some
holes into the plastic piece and just glued the toothpicks in place and that's
really it for building the mass all you have to do is let that dry and then
paint it out using the same technique is on the boat last step is the sail I've
included two different ones in the template one that has this realistic
sail texture but it doesn't have that logo on it that was specific to my
campaign and I thought it would be better to leave a blank for you guys
I've also included a totally blank one in case you don't have a color printer
or you want to do your own weathering techniques with paints anyways once you
print them out the sail of your choice I decided to use these grommets that I
bought from Walmart to make this sale removable from the
mast this way I can make many different sails and use this boat many different
times without tying it to a specific location and I think it looks pretty
good once I was happy with it I decided to
crumple up the paper a bit on the lines in the print to give it a bit more of a
3d look and of course if you want your sails to have some sort of a logo on it
you can take my template and use or Photoshop and overlay your own graphic
